thread.title: #DressLikeAWoman: Women post what they wear to work in response to reports of Donald Trump's stringent dress code
thread.title_full: #DressLikeAWoman: Women post what they wear to work in response to reports of Donald Trump's stringent dress code

author: Helena Horton
title: #DressLikeAWoman: Women post what they wear to work in response to reports of Donald Trump's stringent dress code
text:
#DressLikeAWoman: Women post what they wear to work in response to reports of Donald Trump's stringent dress code Women have pointed out they don't need to wear skirts to do their job Credit: Twitter Helena Horton 3 February 2017 • 1:34pm 
W omen have responded with humour and fury in response to reports that Donald Trump prefers his female staff members to "dress like women", and some "felt pressured to wear dresses" when they worked for him. 
The report came from news site Axios , and has made quite a splash online after an unnamed source who allegedly worked on the campaign told the website that "women who worked in Trump's campaign field offices — folks who spend more time knocking on doors than attending glitzy events — felt pressure to wear dresses to impress Trump." 
The Telegraph has contacted the White House for a statement about these claims. 
Women have responded to the claims by beginning the hashtag #DressLikeAWoman, posting pictures of female astronauts, footballers and scientists as well as themselves at work. 
They are pointing out that they do not need to wear dresses or high heels to do their job properly. This skirts versus trousers debate has been raging for decades #dresslikeawoman Katharine Hepburn when harangued about not wearing a skirt: "I’ll wear it to your funeral.” pic.twitter.com/8yz2UvCtX3 — Dubhthaigh Adams (@lizduffyadams) February 3, 2017 This surgeon is dressed like a woman That's me on the left wearing my favorite outfit #DressLikeAWoman pic.twitter.com/M8UnQ2pBwE — Rebecca Alleyne, MD (@BeckyAlleyneMD) February 3, 2017 Inspirational women from across the world have been highlighted on the hashtag Bring your baby. Teach her to vote. Teach her to govern. Dress like Licia Ronzulli in European Parliment. #DressLikeAWoman pic.twitter.com/t3jNEPVaC2 It would be a bit impractical to wear a skirt to this job Christa Mcauliffe knew how to #DressLikeAWoman . Trump, it's your turn to #ActLikeAPresident . #TheResistance pic.twitter.com/95M5jMsWYq — #TheResistance (@AynRandPaulRyan) February 3, 2017 People have taken it as an opportunity to celebrate influential women A photo posted by Noor Al-Hajri | نور الهاجري (@nooralhajri) on Feb 2, 2017 at 11:50pm PST Women from popular culture... A photo posted by Katherine Moore (@kate_offtheleash) on Feb 3, 2017 at 4:06am PST ...sports A photo posted by Ashley Amin (@ashleyamin_) on Feb 3, 2017 at 4:01am PST ...and politics
